channel.title: Advent-of-Code on Edd Mann
channel.description: Recent content in Advent-of-Code on Edd Mann

item.title: Solving the Advent of Code 2023 calendar in Kotlin and Swift
item.description: Another year, another Advent of Code, another excuse to explore new languages. After my recent exploration into PWAs this past year, I wanted a reason to explore Kotlin and Swift, two languages equipped for native mobile (Android and iOS) development. Before delving into the mobile domain, I wanted to see what each language had to offer. In this post, I will document my experience completing the Advent of Code 2023 calendar in both Kotlin and Swift.

item.title: Solving the Advent of Code 2022 calendar using my own programming language, santa-lang
item.description: December has come and gone, and the dust has settled on completing the Advent of Code 2022 calendar. As highlighted in my previous post, I wanted to complete this year’s puzzles using my own programming language, santa-lang, which I have tailored to help aid in solving such problems. In this post, I want to discuss this experience, how the language aided in solution development, and where additions or changes were made to improve it along the way.

item.title: Designing santa-lang, a language for solving Advent of Code puzzles
item.description: Over the past several years, I have been slowly working my way through the previous Advent of Code calendars. For each calendar, I opt to solve the puzzles in a new programming language to familiarise myself with other ways of understanding and working. However, there comes a time in each calendar when I grow to dislike some aspect of the language. So I had an idea… why not give this whole programming language design a go? That way, if I grow to dislike the language, I only have myself to blame!

item.title: Solving the Advent of Code 2021 calendar on a Raspberry Pi Pico
item.description: Over the past year or so, I have been interested in microcontrollers and finding ways I can look to use them within personal projects. Having just completed the Advent of Code 2021 calendar in C, I thought it would be interesting to see how many of these solutions I could get to run on the constrained hardware of a Raspberry Pi Pico. In this article, I will discuss how I went about achieving this, presenting the solutions’ answers on a Pimoroni Display via an interactive menu (with paging).

item.title: Solving the Advent of Code 2021 calendar using C in under half-a-second
item.description: Since being introduced to the world of Advent of Code just prior to the 2020 calendar starting, I subsequently spent the majority of 2021 completing (and documenting) the 2015, 2016 and 2017 calendars. For the 2021 calendar, I decided that it would be interesting (and challenging) to complete the calendar in C, with an initial solution written in Python to meet the daily aspect of the challenge. Additionally, with C being such a performant language, I also wanted to set the goal of ensuring that the entire C calendar was solvable on a single CPU core in under half a second (inspired by this blog post). In this post, I wish to discuss how I went about achieving this goal (spoiler: 410315 Î¼s (0.410 s) on average) and the hurdles I faced along the way.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 11 - Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators
item.description: On the eleventh day of Advent of Code 2016, we are tasked with moving all the supplied Generators and Microchips to the top floor using a single elevator.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 10 - Balance Bots
item.description: On the tenth day of Advent of Code 2016, we come across a factory in which many robots are zooming around, handing small microchips to each other.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 9 - Explosives in Cyberspace
item.description: On the ninth day of Advent of Code 2016, we are asked to calculate the decompressed length of a file.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 8 - Two-Factor Authentication
item.description: On the eighth day of Advent of Code 2016, we are required to work out what a smashed LCD screen would have displayed.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 7 - Internet Protocol Version 7
item.description: On the seventh day of Advent of Code 2016, we are required to determine which IPv7 addresses support TLS (Transport-Layer Snooping) and SSL (Super-Secret Listening).

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 6 - Signals and Noise
item.description: On the sixth day of Advent of Code 2016, we are required to determine the error-corrected message that is being sent to Santa.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 5 - How About a Nice Game of Chess?
item.description: On the fifth day of Advent of Code 2016, we are asked to calculate the password for a security door in Easter Bunny HQ.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 4 - Security Through Obscurity
item.description: On the fourth day of Advent of Code 2016, we are asked to validate and decrypt a listing of room names.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 3 - Squares With Three Sides
item.description: On the third day of Advent of Code 2016, we are asked to work out how many valid triangles are present in a given listing.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 2 - Bathroom Security
item.description: On the second day of Advent of Code 2016, we are asked to work out what a bathroom code is based on the supplied instructions.

item.title: Advent of Code 2016 - Day 1 - No Time for a Taxicab
item.description: Having enjoyed documenting my progress in completing the Advent of Code 2015 advent calendar in TypeScript, I have decided to do the same for 2016. However, for this year, I wish to instead explore Python.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 25 - Let It Snow
item.description: On the twenty-fifth day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to help Santa boot up his weather machine.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 24 - It Hangs in the Balance
item.description: On the twenty-fourth day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to help Santa balance his sleigh based on all the presents he has to carry.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 23 - Opening the Turing Lock
item.description: On the twenty-third day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to help ‘Little Jane Marie’ run a program on a computer she got for Christmas.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 22 - Wizard Simulator 20XX
item.description: On the twenty-second day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to help ‘Little Henry Case’ beat the boss in another video game he is stuck on.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 21 - RPG Simulator 20XX
item.description: On the twenty-first day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to help ‘Little Henry Case’ beat the boss in a new video game he got for Christmas.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 20 - Infinite Elves and Infinite Houses
item.description: On the twentieth day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to help work out how many presents the Elves will deliver to specific houses.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 19 - Medicine for Rudolph
item.description: On the nineteenth day of Advent of Code 2015, Rudolph is sick, and we have been tasked with helping develop the custom-made medicine required.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 18 - Like a GIF For Your Yard
item.description: On the eighteenth day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to re-arrange the light show we created on a previous day.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 17 - No Such Thing as Too Much
item.description: On the seventeenth day of Advent of Code 2015, the elves bought 150 litres of eggnog that we are asked to fit in the supplied containers for refrigeration.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 16 - Aunt Sue
item.description: On the sixteenth day of Advent of Code 2015, we are tasked with working out which Aunt Sue (there are 500!?) sent us a gift, so we can send them a thank you card.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 15 - Science for Hungry People
item.description: On the fifteenth day of Advent of Code 2015, we are tasked with finding the right balance of ingredients to make the perfect milk-dunking cookie recipe.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 14 - Reindeer Olympics
item.description: On the fourteenth day of Advent of Code 2015, Santa wants to find out who is the fastest reindeer.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 13 - Knights of the Dinner Table
item.description: On the thirteenth day of Advent of Code 2015, we are tasked with finding the optimal seating arrangement for our family holiday feast.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 12 - JSAbacusFramework.io
item.description: On the twelfth day of Advent of Code 2015, Santa’s Accounting-Elves need help balancing the books after a recent order.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 11 - Corporate Policy
item.description: On the eleventh day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to help Santa pick a new memorable password, as his last one has expired.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 10 - Elves Look, Elves Say
item.description: On the tenth day of Advent of Code 2015, the Elves are playing a game of look-and-say, in which we are asked to find several terms in the sequence.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 9 - All in a Single Night
item.description: On the ninth day of Advent of Code 2015, Santa wants us to examine some new locations (and distances) he is required to visit.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 8 - Matchsticks
item.description: On the eighth day of Advent of Code 2015, Santa wants to know how much space his newly digitised list will take up when stored.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 7 - Some Assembly Required
item.description: On the seventh day of Advent of Code 2015, we are tasked with helping little Bobby Tables assemble a circuit (wires and bitwise logic gates) that Santa brought him for Christmas.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 6 - Probably a Fire Hazard
item.description: On the sixth day of Advent of Code 2015, we are tasked with trying to win the holiday house decorating contest - by designing the best light sequence ð¡.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 5 - Doesn't He Have Intern-Elves For This?
item.description: On the fifth day of Advent of Code 2015, Santa needs help figuring out which strings in his text file are naughty or nice - a.k.a best load up a Regular Expression tester!

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 4 - The Ideal Stocking Stuffer
item.description: On the fourth day of Advent of Code 2015, Santa needs help mining some AdventCoins ðµ.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 3 - Perfectly Spherical Houses in a Vacuum
item.description: On the third day of Advent of Code 2015, we are asked to help determine (based on supplied directions) how many houses Santa (and Robo-Santa) will deliver presents to.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 2 - I Was Told There Would Be No Math
item.description: The second day of Advent of Code 2015 brings us a small maths problem by way of Elves running low on wrapping paper. With the present dimensions (perfect right rectangular prisms) provided, we are to answer several related questions.

item.title: Advent of Code 2015 - Day 1 - Not Quite Lisp
item.description:
This past December, a fellow colleague introduced us to Advent of Code. What initially started out as completing each daily 2020 puzzle in my own time soon turned into a daily obsession, and in turn, an incredible learning experience shared amongst the team.

Having completed the 2020 calendar at the end of last year, over the past couple of weeks we have begun working through the previous calendars. Over the coming months, I hope to record each of my solutions, with the goal of completing all the previous puzzles just in time for the 2021 calendar to commence.
